United States Department of State / Foreign relations of the United States. Conference at Quebec, 1944
			(1944)

 Substantive preparatory papers, pp. 48-278
			
 PDF (86.4 MB) 



Page 210


THE SECOND QUEBEC CONFERENCE
directly to the Italian Government on such matters as the treatment of
Italian prisoners of war here.'3
 Territorial Problens. Our preliminary studies have been based on
the criteria: (1) territory should not be taken from Italy merely to
punish a defeated enemy or reward an ally; (2) ethnic considerations
should predominate, though economic and strategic factors would be
kept in mind; (3) as to colonies, native welfare is the first concern;
other colonial empires should not be aggrandized by the addition of
Italian colonies; and, if Italian colonies are placed under international
trusteeship, efforts might be made to place under similar trusteeship
at least somne other colonial possessions.
 In order not to prejudice final settlements, we have advised the
extension of Allied Military Government to all metropolitan territory
within the 1939 frontiers as liberated; administration thereof by
Anglo-American military forces exclusively; and in disputed areas
the employment of more Allied and fewer local Italian officials than
elsewhere in Italy.
" See Foreign Relations, 1944, vol. iII, p. 1146.
Hopkins Papers
The Chief of the Economic Section of the Allied Control Comimmission
 for I taly (O'Dwyer) to the President'
SECRET [WASHINGTON,] September 8, 1944.
 REPORT TO THE PRESIDENT ON THE ITALIAN SITUATION
 I. IEALTH, SUPPLY AND SHIPPING SITUATION
 The plight of the Italian people is serious as a result of Nazi and
Fascist rule and the battle destruction on its soil. The accumulated re-
suit of years of undernourishment and the destruction caused by the
fighting has already begun to show up and is likely to show up in ac-
celerated form in the near future. From available information, includ-
ing the official Allied government medical opinion, the general health
of the people seems to be bad. Serious outbreaks of illness are to be
expected beginning with winter conditions. The low resistance of the
people is said to be the result of continued low consumption under
Fascist occupation. The dangerous period is said to be from January
to July, 1945. Increased food supply is prescribed by the Allied Con-
 1 The source text is filed with the following undated handwritten chit:
"MR.
HOPKINS:-This is the memo of which I spoke to you last evening. BILL O'DWYER".
It is not known whether O'Dwyer actually gave a copy to Roosevelt, but, if
not,
he presumably gave the President the gist of the memorandum during a meeting
which he and Crowley had with Roosevelt at 11:15 a.m., September 8 (Roose-
velt Papers).
